senses.de: A planned way to do something to achieve a specific goal.
senses.ex: Her strategy to win the game was to score early.

Tips.title: Specific Goals
Tips.description: Understanding 'strategy' involves knowing precise objectives it's trying to achieve.
Tips.example: The team's strategy was focused on improving customer satisfaction.

Tips.title: Long-Term Vision
Tips.description: 'Strategy' often implies a long-term plan, not just immediate actions.
Tips.example: Their academic strategy was designed to rank top in the nation over a decade.

Tips.title: Adaptability Importance
Tips.description: Strategies should be adaptable to changing circumstances while pursuing goals.
Tips.example: The coach adjusted the game strategy at halftime to respond to the opponent's defense.

senses.de: In military, the art of planning and directing large military movements and operations.
senses.ex: The general's strategy led to an astonishing victory.

Tips.title: Military Context
Tips.description: The word 'strategy' in military context refers to large-scale planning, beyond immediate battles.
Tips.example: Napoleon was known for his grand strategy in military campaigns.

Tips.title: Strategic vs. Tactical
Tips.description: 'Strategy' involves overarching plans, while 'tactics' are the specific methods used within those plans.
Tips.example: The army's strategy was to contain the enemy, using guerrilla tactics as needed.

senses.de: In business, a detailed plan for achieving success.
senses.ex: We need a new marketing strategy to increase sales.

Tips.title: Business Success
Tips.description: In business, 'strategy' entails a well-thought-out plan aimed at market success and competition.
Tips.example: Their business strategy involved investing heavily in research and development.

Tips.title: Customer Focus
Tips.description: Business strategies often prioritize customer needs and market trends.
Tips.example: The customer-centric strategy drove the company's product innovation efforts.

senses.de: In politics, a plan of action designed to achieve a major goal.
senses.ex: Their election strategy focuses on reaching out to younger voters.

Tips.title: Political Agenda
Tips.description: Political strategies are about gaining support to achieve set political objectives.
Tips.example: The candidate's strategy included targeting undecided voters.

Tips.title: Influence and Persuasion
Tips.description: Strategy in politics often involves persuasive tactics to shape public opinion.
Tips.example: The senator used a media strategy to build support for the bill.

Approach.wordDefinition:
Approach means the way of dealing with things or people. It is a general concept, method or idea of how to do something.

For example, if one wants to improve their grades in school, their approach might be to study more and practice doing more exercises.

Strategy refers to a plan of action that is designed to achieve a specific goal. It is a more detailed and specific plan than an approach.

In simple terms, Approach is like the manner in which you plan to do something while Strategy is a much more detailed and specific plan of how to achieve a particular goal.

Approach is generally applicable in any area of life where one needs to deal with situations while Strategy is usually applicable in business and military contexts.

Blueprint.wordDefinition:
Blueprint refers to a detailed plan or diagram that shows how something will be built or created. For example, a blueprint might show the exact measurements and materials needed to build a house or piece of furniture.

A blueprint is more focused on the specific details of how to create something, while a strategy is more focused on the broader plan for achieving a goal.

However, both are important in different contexts. Blueprints are applicable in fields such as architecture, engineering, and manufacturing, where precise planning and execution are critical.

Manoeuvre.wordDefinition:
A manoeuvre is a specific action that is taken in order to achieve a goal or objective. For example, in a game of chess, a manoeuvre might be moving a pawn forward to protect a more valuable piece.

Strategy is a more general approach or plan that is taken to achieve a larger goal. It involves considering different manoeuvres and tactics that can be used in order to achieve a desired outcome.

In summary, manoeuvres are specific actions that are taken in order to achieve a goal or objective, while strategy is a more general approach or plan that involves considering different options and tactics in order to achieve a larger goal or objective.

Methodology.wordDefinition:
Methodology refers to the specific processes, techniques, and procedures used to conduct research or achieve a goal. It is a systematic approach to solving a problem, completing a project or achieving a result.

Methodology is used more in technical fields like software engineering or scientific research.

Methodology refers to the specific steps you take to achieve your goal, while strategy refers to the overall plan that guides those specific steps.

Outline.wordDefinition:
An outline is a plan that provides a general idea of what needs to be accomplished, usually in the form of a list or bullet points.

A strategy is a more detailed and comprehensive plan that outlines specific steps and tactics to achieve a particular goal or objective.

Plan.wordDefinition:
A plan is a set of steps that you take to reach a specific goal, whereas a strategy is a broader plan that outlines a long-term approach to achieving success.

A plan is typically more short-term and focused, while a strategy considers the bigger picture and incorporates multiple plans.

For example, if you want to do well on a math test, your plan might involve studying for a set amount of time each day, doing practice problems, and asking your teacher for help on tricky concepts.

Your strategy might involve setting a goal to maintain a certain GPA throughout high school, and following a plan that incorporates studying, attending extra help sessions, and seeking out tutoring if needed.

In general, plans are applicable for short-term goals or specific tasks, while strategies are useful for achieving long-term objectives or navigating a complex situation.

Scheme.wordDefinition:
Scheme typically refers to a plan that is usually clever or sometimes even dishonest, and is often used to achieve a specific goal or advantage.

A scheme is often seen as sneaky or underhanded and can sometimes be illegal.

A scheme is a sneaky or dubious plan to achieve a certain goal, while a strategy is a carefully planned-out approach to achieving a larger goal.

Schemes may be used for personal gain or advantage, while strategies are typically developed in business, military, or political contexts.

Tactic.wordDefinition:
Tactics are specific actions or steps that are taken to achieve a particular short-term goal. It's like the smaller steps taken to reach the end goal.

A tactic for achieving that strategy could be to focus on improving defense or practicing specific plays.

In business, a strategy could be to expand the company's market share. Tactics to achieve this might include offering sales promotions, targeted marketing campaigns, and increasing customer satisfaction.

Strategy is the overall approach, while tactics are specific actions taken to achieve the strategy.

quotes.Text: Business is another kind of world that I don't think is as passionate. It is not the pressure to perform as you have in football. It is more about strategy, skill, about how you deal with all the information you have. Some of the things from football I can bring to business, and some things from business I can bring to football.
quotes.Title: Spanish Athlete
quotes.Name: Gerard Pique

quotes.Text: President Obama is highly concerned with education. He's a champion on early-childhood development strategies. So I like the work he's doing, and I support it, and I realise that he's one of very few political leaders around the world that actually has early-childhood development strategise at the top of his agenda.
quotes.Title: Musician
quotes.Name: Shakira

quotes.Text: What we need to do is always lean into the future; when the world changes around you and when it changes against you - what used to be a tail wind is now a head wind - you have to lean into that and figure out what to do because complaining isn't a strategy.

quotes.Name: Jeff Bezos

quotes.Text: The reason is that till date, in spite of advances in information technology and strategies of information, the written word in the form of books still remains one of humanity's most enduring legacies.

quotes.Text: It's important to have the right strategy. I can't commit to things or fight like I used to. I can't just bang it out. I have to be more intelligent in training and in fighting.

quotes.Text: The biggest risk is not taking any risk... In a world that is changing really quickly, the only strategy that is guaranteed to fail is not taking risks.

quotes.Text: The entrance strategy is actually more important than the exit strategy.

quotes.Text: Self-delusion is rarely a good strategy for effective management.

quotes.Text: My father has never influenced the strategy anywhere.
